name: MONKSHOOD
description: 5 showy blue to purple sepals, with the upper sepal forming the hood.
habitat: forest openings, wet meadows and thickets.

name: BURNT-ORANGE AGOSERIS
description: leaves basal, somewhat lobed or toothed; heads with ray flowers only.

name: YELLOW STONECROP
description: leaves succulent (fleshy), in basal (at the plant base) clusters, often deciduous (falling off, not persistent throughout the year) before anthesis (opening of the flower).
habitat: rocky ground at 5,000 to 11,500 feet elevation.

name: DWARF  PUSSYTOES
description: usually with leafy stolons; leaves in basal rosette, white-tomentose on both sides (densely covered with thick-wooly hairs with no distinct orientation); phyllaries (bracts - small leaf-like structures - surrounding composite head) white or sometimes pinkish tips.

name: FRINGED MOUNTAIN SAGE
common_name: fringed sage, silver sage, wormwood, pasture sage
description: leaves finely dissected, silvery-hairy; flowering stems erect.
habitat: dry meadows and slopes at 3,000 to 11,000 feet elevation.

name: AMERICAN BISTORT
common_name: bistort, western bistort, smartweed, knotweed, snakeweed
description: white flowers in a dense cyclindric raceme; (elongated flower cluster with stalked flowers along a main axis); erect slender stem.
habitat: moist or wet meadows and swamps at high elevations.

name: HAREBELL
description: corolla lobed only about 1/3; stems over 2 dm tall; flowers several per stem.
habitat: dry mountain slopes at lower to middle altitudes (7,500 to 11,500 feet).

name: MOUSE-EAR CHICKWEED
description: floral stems with tufts of sterile shoots in leaf axils (angle where leaves join stems); bracts (small leaf-like structures) of the inflorescence (flower cluster) with scarious (dry, thin, papery) margins.
habitat: meadows and openings in pine forests.

name: SPOTTED SAXIFRAGE
description: white petals dotted with purplish red spots; leaves mostly basal, tightly stacked.
habitat: dry areas, along trails, rocky slopes, forest openings and boulder fields.

name: ROSE CROWN
description: flowers in dense clusters, rose colored, resembling red clover; numerous fleshy stem leaves; stout rootstock; in colonies.
habitat: in bogs, seeps, and moist ground of meadows, along streams and pond shores.

name: SUBALPINE LARKSPUR
description: fragrant flowers in terminal, spike-like cluster with small, purple, white-margined petals and 5 deep purple sepals; upper sepal has 3/8in long spur; leaves have 5-7 coarsely toothed lobes.
habitat: moist places such as bogs, stream banks, meadows, seeps, ponds, and forest openings.

name: SHOWY DAISY
description: upper and middle stem leaves glabrous except for ciliate margins (edged with hairs); plants uniformly leafy with middle leaves as large as lower leaves.
habitat: aspen groves, forest margins and openings at 6,000 to 11,000 feet..

name: CHIMING BELLS
description: leaves glabrous (hairless), sometimes with papillae (tiny wart-like structures) above.
habitat: streamsides, near springs, ponds and other very moist areas.

name: SNOWBALL SAXIFRAGE
description: leaves rhomboid (shaped like an equilateral parallelogram), tapering to a short, broad petiole (leaf stalk).
habitat: open areas and rocky slopes that are seasonally moist in spring.

name: FERNLEAF LOUSEWORT
description: much less than 3 feet tall; flowers not streaked with reddish; corolla less than 1.5 inch long; lower lip not reaching the tip of the galea (hood-shaped sepal or petal).

name: ELEPHANT HEAD
description: flower resembles an elephant's head; flowers in an elongated spike (unstalked flowers along a main axis).

name: MARSH MARIGOLD
description: erect leafless flower stalk, white flower with prominent yellow center.
habitat: large patches in bogs, marshes, soggy meadows, along lakes and ponds.

name: RED PRICKLY CURRANT
description: low spreading shrub; leaves pubescent and glandular; spines 3 at node.

name: MOUNTAIN BLUEBERRY
description: leaves more than 10 mm., serrate from base to end; branchlets angled, green.
habitat: forest openings and rocky areas, 7500 - 12,500 ft.
